description: The search for worlds beyond our Sun.

slides.title: What is an Exoplanet?
slides.content:
# Alien Worlds ğŸ‘½

A planet orbiting a star other than our Sun.
- First confirmed in 1992 (around a pulsar).
- First sun-like star planet in 1995 (51 Pegasi b).
- We now know thousands exist.

slides.title: Detection: Transit Method
slides.content:
# The Mini Eclipse ğŸŒ”

Planet passes *in front* of the star.
- Star's brightness dips slightly.
- Tells us the **Size** (Radius) and Orbit period.
- Kepler and TESS missions used this.

slides.title: Detection: Radial Velocity
slides.content:
# The Wobble ğŸ’ƒ

Planet's gravity tugs the star back and forth.
- Starlight shifts color (Doppler shift).
- Tells us the **Mass** of the planet.
- Bias towards big plants near stars.

slides.title: Direct Imaging
slides.content:
# Taking a Photo ğŸ“¸

Blocking the star's light (Coronagraph) to see the faint planet.
- Very hard (Like seeing a firefly next to a spotlight).
- Works best for hot, young, distant planets.

slides.title: Hot Jupiters
slides.content:
# Surprise Giants ğŸŒ‹

First planets found were Gas Giants orbiting extremely close (days) to their stars.
- Tidally locked (one side always hot).
- Proved planets can migrate.

slides.quizQuestion: The Transit Method detects a planet by observing:

slides.title: Super-Earths
slides.content:
# The Missing Size ğŸŒ

Planets between Earth and Neptune in size.
- Most common type in galaxy.
- Not found in our solar system.
- Could be rocky giants or mini-gas planets.

slides.title: Habitable Zone
slides.content:
# Goldilocks Zone ğŸ»

Distance where water can exist as liquid.
- Too Close: Steam (Venus).
- Too Far: Ice (Mars).
- Just Right: Liquid (Earth).
Dependent on star's heat (Red dwarfs have close zones).

slides.title: Red Dwarf Systems
slides.content:
# Common Neighbors ğŸ”´

M-Dwarfs are 75% of stars.
- Planets orbit close (Year = few days).
- **TRAPPIST-1**: System with 7 Earth-sized planets packed tight.
- Risk: Solar flares might strip atmosphere.

slides.title: Rogue Planets
slides.content:
# Orphans ğŸŒ‘

Planets without a star.
- Ejected during chaotic formation.
- Wandering the dark galaxy alone.
- Might outnumber stars!

slides.title: Atmopsheric Analysis
slides.content:
# Tasting the Air ğŸ‘…

Transit Spectroscopy.
- Starlight filters through planet rim.
- Missing colors reveal chemicals ($H_2O, CO_2, CH_4$).
- JWST is doing this now.

slides.title: Biosignatures
slides.content:
# Signs of Life ğŸ¦ 

Gases that shouldn't be together unless life maintains them.
- Example: Oxygen + Methane.
- They react quickly, so something is replenishing them.

slides.quizQuestion: The Habitable Zone is defined by the possibility of:

slides.title: Drake Equation
slides.content:
# Are we alone? ğŸ‘½

$$N = R_* \cdot f_p \cdot n_e \cdot f_l \cdot f_i \cdot f_c \cdot L$$

Estimates active civilizations.
We know planets are common ($f_p \approx 1$). We don't know lifespan ($L$).

Fermi Paradox: "Where is everybody?"

slides.title: Earth 2.0
slides.content:
# The Holy Grail ğŸ†

Goal: Find an Earth-sized planet, in habitable zone, around a Sun-like star, with an atmosphere.
- Haven't found a perfect twin yet.
- Found many "cousins".

slides.title: Proxima Centauri b
slides.content:
# Next Door ğŸšª

Closest exoplanet (4.2 light-years).
- Earth-mass.
- Habitable zone of Red Dwarf.
- Likely tidally locked and blasted by flares.
- Destination for Breakthrough Starshot probes.

slides.title: Formation Theories
slides.content:
# Rethinking ğŸ’­

Data challenged models.
- **Migration**: Planets move.
- **Instability**: Planets scatter.
- Solar systems are diverse!

slides.title: Technosignatures
slides.content:
# Advanced Aliens ğŸ—¼

Looking for pollution, artificial lights, or mega-structures (Dyson Spheres).
- Distinguishing from natural phenomena is hard.

slides.title: Exoplanet Summary
slides.content:
# Recap ğŸ“

- Planets are **Everywhere** (more planets than stars).
- Most are weird (Hot Jupiters, Super Earths).
- **Transit** and **Wobble** find them.
- The hunt for life is on!
